values:
<font color="blue" size="1">I use this name in a few different places.  I have another one somewhere else, and a third in person. Here, I prefer to be Lebannen, even if you do know one or both of the others. If you want to know why, ask and I'll try to explain it to you.

This place is, for me, mainly about the porn and chocolate.  It contains links, references, etc to material which some people may find offensive, or at least surprising.  If you're under eighteen, please don't look too closely, as there is bound to be something you shouldn't get caught looking at - but then, this is Livejournal, what did you expect?

If you are someone who knows me elsewhere, under this name or avatar, or if you think you know me in person, it would be great if you'd leave a note to say hi - anonymous comments are possible if you don't have a livejournal or don't want me to know your LJ name, and all comments will be screened so that no-one else can see them.</font>

If you don't read or , this probably won't make much sense. So go and read this lj_biz post. Or if you don't want to read it all, the short verion is that LJ has created a new security feature thing to filter material which is potentially NSFW / not appropriate for the kiddies. This may affect the way you can see or access posts on LJ, including the way some posts show up on your flist. Part of the lj_biz post says (emphasis mine):
How Will This Affect My Search Results? There are three Safe Search filtering options, which are as follows: Use Moderate Filtering (default setting): Filters only explicit adult content. Use Strict Filtering: Filters both adult concepts and explicit adult content. Do Not Filter Results: All search results will display, including those marked as explicit adult content and adult concepts. You can change your search settings on the Settings page.
Don't know about you, but I take exception to people making new defaults that limit the information I receive. So I went off to the Settings page to change it. And when I got there, I found a whole new feature not mentioned at all in the lj-biz post. It looks a little something like this:
Viewing Adult Content Collapse adult-oriented material written by other users: [Dropdown menu offers the following options: Do not collapse / Collapse explicit adult content only / Collapse adult concepts and explicit adult content]
If you do not have an appropriate birthdate on file in your Profile, this will be set to the most restrictive option, with the other two greyed out. Fixing this allowed me to see a post on my flist without the auto-generated 'adult concepts' cut-tag; I don't know what the default setting is for people with a birthdate on file. I can see how this might be a handy feature to have, in that it auto-cuts potentially NSFW posts for those who read their flists in public / at work, but I'm not impressed with the way it's been implemented by default.

So, let's see if I can write some tags without cutting and pasting anything (it really helps not to write "lj-cute", for starters)...
So, here we have an oil refinery, a couple of tankers, a little local ferry and a couple of yachts. Note also the flames coming out of a chimney, and hint of black smoke.
Somewhat later in the day, see that black cloud up there? All came out of those chimnies. Also, see that little meandering bit of ... not-quite-river at the bottom left of the picture? It seems to spend most of the day catching the light and trying to look photogenic - I suspect I'm going to be spending quite a while trying to catch a good photo of it. Might take a while, starting from this point. It all looked much more in-focus while I was trying to take it, too. I'll do something about that, too. So yes, I have a new camera, it's not fantastic but it was cheapish and means I can photospam you on a daily basis, aren't you lucky?

oh, whoops, off islandsitting again. Will possibly be online there this time, if I've been left the dialup instructions. Othjerwise, will be vaguely around at ... vague times, for the next ... while. umm. Until the 27th? something like that. have fun.

gosh, a very simple meme! I might be able to do it! 1. My username is , because I like the name. This is despite the fact that the original Lebannen is a fictional character who is male, and I am not. (well, not male anyway. I sometimes doubt my own relationship with reality, but not terribly seriously). Some people may believe that the name has some sekrit connection with my real name, and are welcome to continue doing so if they so desire. The surname 'Luitreath' was completely made up (using James Lovelock's method of getting a name for his company; take something obscure, and mis-spell it), and never used to get any hits on google. Now it gets two, and oh look, they're both me. This has possibly scuppered my chances of ever calling a company 'Luitreath Ltd' and not having any connection with my lj-identity. I can live with this. 2. My journal is titled 'Stuff and nonsense', because some of it is stuff and some of it is nonsense. Some of it is also nonsensical stuff; you could draw a Venn diagram of it if you were bored enough. 3. The journal's subtitle is, uh, [goes off to c&p it] '(but probably more of the latter)', which should be pretty self-explanatory in the context of the title. 4. My friends page is called 'Romance and knitting', which is a Good Omens reference that seemed amusing at the time. I don't change these things very often, and have yet to think of a better title anyway. 5. My default userpic is my new hat what I made in needlepoint. I think I already explained about it. It is also as close as I'm getting to something seasonal this year, being all colourful and whatnot. ... and if it's so simple how come this is the second third edit? Oh yes, that'd be because I clearly can't type today. Le sigh. *headdesk*

I have a new icon! This is my latest and most ridiculously complicated needlepoint project (the pictures link to larger images). It's also a hat which is currently, annoyingly, just a bit too big. Unfortuntely I don't think my head's ever going to get big enough for it to fit comfortably, so either I will have to find some amazing way of adapting it, or never wear it. Or possibly both. Sort-of (but not really) relatedly, someone is trying to sell cross-stitch patterns of SGA characters on eBay. 170*230 stitches, which works out at over a foot tall. In cross-stitch. Which is mostly background (or don't you do background in cross-stitch? I don't know). That's - oh god, I just checked - that's a lifesize picture of Sheppard. At 14 dpi. and somebody has bid on it. More SGA - how did I not notice that Caldwell is the former AD Skinner? I'd read fic predisposing me not to like him before I ever saw the show, and then on sight suddenly found it impossible to hate him but without recognising him. aaand I'm sure there was something else.
hmm, someone has a birthday today. woe, for I have no card to give. I hope you have cake and pie instead, and maybe a new home. many, many thoughts and hopes for a happy birthday, cee-est x
Happy Birthday ! (just don't try to look too closely at all the banners, some people may have strayed in from another event...)

I now have glasses. I've never had glasses before. I think I'm possibly the only person on my flist that didn't - ok, some of you I don't know about ... oh, hang on, Anna? Oh, well, anyway, I am now joining the glasses-owning section of the population. Only problem is that I don't have the glasses yet, as they are in the post (hopefully, anyway). And I can't read the screen on this computer too well. and it's not my computer, so I can't go fiddling with the brightness to see if that's part of the problem, as well as having the screen in a completely diferent place to what I'm used to. This means I can't read fic right at the moment. THIS IS ANNOYING ME. My laptop has been sent away and taken into an Apple store and been sent away from there too and will hopefully be back from them end of next week and hopefully be back with me by the end of the following week. Maybe then I'll stop whining, or, at least, cut it down a fair bit. ... this is a public post, so any lurkers please note, my personal circumstances might be changing somewhat from January, and if they do I'll be going mostly friendslocked. Any photos I get round to posting will probably stay public, though.

So somewhere out there in the white-trimmed shades of grey out of the window is a boy who's just rowed across the Atlantic. Crazy boy. But, y'know, rather an achievement. Congratulations, Oliver Hicks! It's a bit of a shame that his other support website spells its title wrong, and that both of them identify the finish line as "Bishop's Rock" when it's "Bishop Rock", but they don't seem to have any more obvious things wrong. And my current music was a complete coincidence.
Little Brother, if you are looking for my lj, well done, you've found it. If that really was your uni friend's you were looking for, then fine, you're not going to read this.
Happy birthday, <lj user="alienspacebat">! I hope you have a wonderful day.

There is more SoHW. I am going to read it again, and I am going to go to bed. Then I am probably going to read a bit of she. And it is finally raining. I hope it does so for more than five minutes, because we really haven't had rain here, despite the rest of the country being hit by thunderstorms and flash floods and whatnot. And rain at night is always nice when you are indoors in the warm and want to sleep.

*blinks*  my flist skip=20 has only 19 entries, and it give me links to the next and previous 19 entries. The links actually go to perfectly normal pages with 20 entries each. I'm confused, but then, I've been quite easily confusable today. *yawns*

You know you've been reading too much fanfiction when, in an Actual Published Novel, you stop and go OMGWTF WHY WASN'T THERE A WARNING FOR THIS? and it takes you a while to realise that most books do not in fact warn you explicitly that there is likely to be a graphic description of hideous torture ahead, especially when the author has spent quite a lot of the book mentioning the cloud of rumours surrounding Madame's household. This novel brought to you by the creator of Suraklin, the Alketch and the Rat-God would have worked, I suppose. So given that I know about them, yes, I should have been sufficiently warned. But none of them were so graphic - and none of them had a little historical note at the end of the book saying oh yes, that bit was real. probably. I'm not sure whether that made it worse or not, actually. On a complete change of subject, I am mildly amused by the typo in the title of one of the books currently going through DP: Hymns for Christian devotion: especially adapted to the Universalist demonination.

so, I should have been reading serious things, but no, I've been watching the hitchhiker's guide - the tv series, of course, what with the absence of cinemas round here. I really don't know why they're showing it now, especially when I also caught the start of so long and thanks for all the fish on the radio earlier, but, anyway, that's what I've been doing. Now I'll go finish my ironing, oops.

There was a Labour candidate called Jack Davenport. How many people d'you suppose voted for him because they thought they recognised the name??

(why yes, I have been sat here for three hours hitting refresh on the BBC webpage, and yes, I do have to go to work in less than eight hours. and?)

I'm going to go sleep now.

ok, so, I failed my last stats exam. It makes my brain hurt a lot when faced with: in constituency X, Labour have won by a long way but their share of the vote is down 8.3%, the Tories are up 1.9%, etc etc etc. This is a 5.1% swing from Labour to the Tories. How does that work?

A Brief Brief History of Time. With more physics and less gay sex than most of the things I read on the internet, and the odd cameo by Newton's flatmate, etc, etc. It's good, if funnier in some places than others - or it could just be that it's really very late and even the minimal amount of physics left in it has melted my brain. You decide.

<lj-cut text="gratuitous swearing aimed at Firefox">What the fuck, Firefox is not supposed to crash. And it's done it twice in the last three days, for NO FUCKING REASON. and I wasn't even reading porn. Fuck off with the rainbow pizza already.</lj-cut>

Outside, the sky's a perfect gradient of January blues. There are some few things in the way, trees and a telephone pole and the odd left-over cloud, but what I can see from here is blue. Blue like this should be calm, somehow, but listen carefully and it's not, at all. There's Dylan coming through the floorboards and Keane drifting up the stairs, but you don't notice them at once because of the wind, which is bouncing around (mostly) out there, dumping salt on the window, not quite finding the right angle to rattle the frame but slipping inside anyway.

Happy birthday, Cee! Hope you have a fantastic day.
Haha, aren't I clever, man of letters what with the picture being made partly out of letters thanks to the 'random glyph' feature of the mosaic program. Sorry, no larger version available at this time.

Happy birthday,
clicky image for larger version, please tell me if it's not working. All images from my photos folder and my rightclicksaved webpages folder, which explains why so many LJ community icons, and so many copies of my various avatars as well as other people's
So, uh, that Cornish girl on Faking It? Not all Cornish girls are like that. Really.

Dear people who rec things,

it helps if people can actually GET to the fic, you know?  A rec that leads to a javascript menu that tells you that there's a password if you go to thatsite/password.html is NOT VERY FUCKING HELPFUL when thatsite/password.html tells you (in horribly tiny text in a nasty colour scheme) to go join a fucking Yahoo group and trawl around in their archives to find the password when all you want is the story, kthanks.

Whee, only one edit and it all seems to be working! Here be pics:
By way of setting the scene; a fairly small lake, in the grand scheme of things, but there are yachts, nonetheless. Autumn had not yet hit at water level. The first of many: ooh look, we went rowing. So I took photos of the paddles. When you're near trees, the reflections go all green. Fancy that. On the other hand, go further out into the lake or take a picture of the other side of the boat, it goes all blue and you just get the clouds reflected... Ooh looky, half way! This was a boathouse (and, in fact, it still is, unless anything untoward has happened in the last couple of weeks). I liked the stripeyness. Spot the new wallpaper, except that the Save for Web seems to have bleached this quite a bit, it's more purple in real life. uh, this is a blonde in a boat, sporting the latest in compulsory assisted buoyancy. With, like, trees and stuff. (John, if you haven't seen E. in the last six months or so, yes, that really is him)

And now, a public service announcement brought to you courtesy of Jack Chick:
Warning: image is a link to a Chick Tract. I'd never seen these before, despite having heard of them. For the benefit of anyone else who didn't know already, they're... deeply fucked up. And apparently, there are people out there who take them seriously, which is possibly even more fucked up.
Today I have mostly been playing weboggle. badly. but it's still fun.

Hiii. *waves* I have a new icon. It's not quite what I thought it was going to be, but it's close enough. I also have another picture that was nearly an icon, but decided not to be; it should be over there on the right, but I don't always get my code quite right so it may screw up your page or just plain not show up or something. I also have new wallpaper; it looks like something that might be used as a background on a PotC site or something, ripples and sand and sunshine on sea. (clicking on it gets you the 1024*768 version). I'm sure turning it into a jpeg did something less-than-flattering to the colours, but I haven't worked out what to do about that yet. It's ever so slightly fiddled, with a dust and scratches filter run over it, but nothing done with any aim to alter the image from the original. As ever, photo by me, if you want it for anything other than your own personal use please ask first

Never volunteer for anything while in a pub. I should have learnt this by now; maybe writing it down will somehow fix it into my mind, but I doubt it. On Friday night, I agreed to join Little Brother's rowing crew for practice on Sunday morning, since one of them was going to be away. At two o'clock this (Sunday) morning, after having sat up reading pirate smut, I remembered this. At nine o'clock I was out in the rain getting the boat ready. The things we do for our families, eh. So as a recognition of this outstanding piece of selflessness, I present pictures of boats, taken in April and May of this year:
This is the boat we were rowing, crewed here by a variation on a theme of the men's A crew - it was at the start of the racing season, and they didn't have a settled crew then. The crew I went out with this morning was techincally the men's B crew, but ended up so motley as to be more of a farce. In the rain. I now have muscles aching that I had almost forgotten existed. Same evening. These were taken while waiting for the start of a race, but the light was going and all the rest of the pictures I took that day were somewhat rubbish. So here are some from another race: This is not in any way the normal appearance of a racing start line! The Pilot Gig Racing World Championships are held here every May, and the first race of the championships is one great long free-for-all, with ninety boats on the line. A normal race has more like ten gigs taking part. From that first big race, quite near the start. And again, but just coming up to the finish line. And afterwards, all pulled up in front of the most horrible bit of seafront we have here. This one's the SS Prince William, which belongs to the Tall Ships Youth Trust, and is very cool despite the name. It just happened to be passing, one day. It's now somewhere between Ipswich and Antwerp, and spending the rest of the summer in the North Sea, the Channel and the Irish Sea. So it'll probably be back sooner or later.

What with having just reinstalled my OS and started again with all my preferences completely blank, I decided that maybe I needed some new wallpaper. A fair number of the photos I've taken lately looked quite suited to the task, so I set about scanning and rearranging them. Then I thought, well, maybe I'll share them with the world as well - aren't I lovely? They're by no means all that interesting, just snippets and scrappets of (mostly) low-contrast landscapes, but behind the cut you'll find a handful of little photos (and I may have made the small ones a bit too small to really see properly, sorry), some of which are links to 1024*768 wallpapers. If all goes according to plan, the ones that are links will have borders, and the rest won't.
If you look at my icon, you can see that it's a map of two islands close together. At low tide you can walk across a sandbar between them, but for a few hours at high tide they're cut off from each other. Standing looking across at the smaller one on a sunny evening, the view can look a little like this. Same place, same evening, it's a closeup of the tide flowing over the sandbar. A different bit of coastline on a different kind of day, I'm not sure when in the winter it was, but maybe January. Once again the same place, the same day, but this time looking down from a little cliff (that's so small as to barely deserve the name) on water somewhat closer. I think I may have fiddled the contrast a little bit on this one to make it a bit hazier. This bay is just around the corner from the previous, and the photo was taken on a spring evening just after high tide, when the light was doing some very peculiar things. I think the sun had gone behind a cloud before I took it. A sunset. In winter. With the colours slightly fiddled to make it look more like it did in the original. This picture's called On the edge of Sunday. I'm not entirely sure why, but it is. It's also the one I currently have as my wallpaper. Beyond those rocks (seen on a May evening), depending on exactly which direction you're going, you might be able to head in a straight line to South America without seeing any other land on the way, but the Caribbean might be more likely. Head too far to the left and you'll find France or Spain, too far to the right and it'll be Canada.
All pictures by me, if you like any enough to take for yourself please leave a comment, if anyone passing wants to reproduce them anywhere other than on their own computer for their own use, please ask first.

I just spent today's pay on eBay. I only started work again on Monday, but it's so nice to have the thought of money again. Even if I really don't have enough shelfspace. But as a bonus, here's something which takes up no shelfspace: Spring photospam! (If you get pissed off with people posting photos that aren't behind cuts, tell me, and I will stop doing it).
This was the view from my back garden, yesterday afternoon. These are the only flowers we have at the moment, apart from the pink triffids which don't like being photographed. They're rather nice, but I have no idea what they are called, beyond being tulips of some sort. (The pink triffids are Geranium anemonifolium, apparently. But there aren't any pictures of them.) Once again, it's the view out of the window at work. This is actually the reason I have the digicam at the moment; we're meant to be taking pictures for adverts. I think that everything we've got so far is crap, and I'm going to have to go in early tomorrow before there are any messy customers about, and try and get something sorted. My boss took what would have been a lovely, sunny picture yesterday, but didn't seem to notice that all the rubbish had been left just outside the door. We'll see what we can do... Eh... a bay, a boat, some more islands over there *waves, vaguely*. Just like a hundred and one other holiday snapshots. So, this is a boat that's been wheeled out of its shed so that someone can escape from his houseguests and sit in the sun painting it. Which is fair enough. But he wouldn't let me take a photo of him, so you get the boat and a bit more of the same bay as above. The strangely rectangular patch of pale yellow in front of the darker yellow gorse in the background, is the remains of a flower field. The farm has been derelict for twenty-odd years but the bulbs were left in the ground, and the flowers come up every year through the brambles and dead bracken.
If anyone feels like it, they can ask me three questions and I'll provide an answer of sorts.

So, it's virtually midnight and I'm installing an ftp client... why can't I just go to sleep. like a normal person?? Evidently I don't do normal very well. Quite why my old ftp client wouldn't work, I don't know, but if it's the only casualty of installing OS X.3 then I don't mind at all.... so, yeah, ftp. This means photospam, here goes - first off, the icon *points, wherever it is*
The lettering reads 'NOT IDLY DO THE LEAVES OF LORIEN FALL' in the Cirth as created by JRR Tolkien, and the leaf brooch is as seen in the LotR films and probably belongs to New Line or something. I just stole them and converted them into a combination of tent stitch and mosaic stitch, worked on fourteen-count canvas in stranded cottons and sparkly bits. The sparkly bits haven't scanned too well, though, and don't show up too much in this version. But I know they're there... The original's about 6.5" tall.
So, backalong a while I was housesitting at a place just up the road. This was the view out of my bedroom window. Pretty, isn't it? I've got some other photos I felt like sharing - I went a bit overboard with the scanner today, but I'm only putting up three right now. They were all taken at the Eden Project in Cornwall, in December.
This is one of the maenads dancing round Dionysos in the middle of the vineyard in the Warm Temperate Biome. They're very cool, and some are scarier than others.
Quoting directly from the blurb, "the Humid Tropics Biome, the largest conservatory in the world, is 240 m long, 110 m wide and 50 m high." What this means is that it's plenty big enough for full-grown palm trees, and plenty more!
OK, so it's not the most exciting picture ever, but I quite like it. It probably helps that it reminds me of a day at a different end of the earth than the one where I'm currently resident - that one had cliffs, caves and many treeferns. It also had a large sealion, some penguins and a lot of rugby fans. Quite a lot of things to get into one day, but it was a while ago... The picture of tree ferns is dedicated to , for making me cry in a good way, and specifically for The End of the World, which has rather larger tree ferns of its own. does that make any sort of sense? probably not, but there you go.

Viggo Mortensen, so many kinds of artist it makes you want to cry (especially when you listen to the 'music', but that's another story...). But who knew that fifteen years ago, when he actually needed the day job, he had a sideline in personalised greetings cards?*
Hope you had a great day, ! * Of course this is true. You're reading it on the internet, aren't you? Oh, and the other story? Already told here by , via a comment in 's journal.

I said to someone the other day that there should be more photospam in the world, and I've been enjoying 's occasional piccies of Scotland, so I thought I'd inflict some of my own photos on y'all. They're all from the cafe I worked at over the summer; here's part of the view out of the window - The rest are
This is about two thirds of the view, complete with evidence of somewhat less-than-leet photoshop skillz where I joined the two photos together - This one's part of the view further round to the left, taken on a foggy day cos that's the only way to get the contrast of the one rock against the carns in the background - And finally, this is what I can see out of the doorway when it's quiet and sunny -
